document.title: General Fink security policy for accepted packages.

preface.p: This document explains security incident handling for packages that have been accepted by Fink. While main responsibility for every accepted package in Fink remains with the respective maintainer, Fink recognises the necessity to offer a uniform policy how to react to security incidents found in software which are offered as Fink packages.

section.name: who
section.title: Who is responsible?
section.p: Every Fink package has a Maintainer. The maintainer of a particular package can be found by typing fink info packagename at the command line prompt. This will return a listing with a field similar to this one: Maintainer: Fink Core Group <fink-core@lists.sourceforge.net>. The maintainer has full responsibility for his/her package(s).

section.name: contact
section.title: Whom shall I contact?
section.p: If there are security incidents within a certain piece of packaged software, you should notify the maintainer of that packages as well as the Fink Core Team. The email of the maintainer can be found within the packages info, the email of the Fink Core Team. is fink-core@lists.sourceforge.net

section.name: prenotifications
section.title: Pre-notifications
section.p: Serious security incidents in a Fink packaged software might require you to pre-notify the maintainer of that package. Since it is possible that the maintainer cannot be reached timely, pre-notification should always be submitted to the Fink Core Team. at fink-core@lists.sourceforge.net

section.name: response
section.title: Response
section.p: Submitted reports about a security incident will be answered by the Fink Core Team., each Maintainer is required by Fink to acknowledge the reported issue individually. In the unlikely event that the maintainer is not available and the maintainer has not acknowledged the report within 24 hours, a note should be sent to the Fink Core Team informing the team that the maintainer might be unresponsive.

In the event, that you attempted to notify the maintainer of the package in question but the mail system returned a delivery error for that email you should notify the Fink Core Team. immediately informing them that the maintainer is unreachable and this package may be updated irrespective of the maintainer.

preface.p: Response time and actions taken greatly depend on the loss severity that is introduced by a particular flaw in the software that has been packaged for Fink. This is a work in progress, it is meant as a pointer for the package maintainers. In any case the Fink Core Team. will take immediate action whenever it feels it is necessary ti protect the Fink using community.

section.name: resptimes
section.title: Response times
section.p: Each package should strive to meet the following response times. For some type of vulnerabilities the Fink Core Team. might choose to take immediate action. If that is the case one of the Core Team members will notify the maintainer of the package in question.

section.name: forced
section.title: Forced updates
section.p: A member of the Fink Core Team. might choose to update a package without waiting for the packages maintainer to take action. This is called a forced update.. Not meeting the maximum required response time for a particular vulnerability in a Fink package also results in a forced update of that package.

section.name: sources
section.title: Acceptable incident Sources.
section.p: As submitter of a security incident in a fink packaged software you have to ensure that the vulnerability of the software also exists on Mac OS X. It the responsibility of the notifying party to ensure that one of the following sources reinforces the reported issue for the particular software in question.

ol.li: AIXAPAR: AIX APAR (Authorised Problem Analysis Report)
BID: Security Focus Bugtraq ID database entry
BUGTRAQ: Posting to Bugtraq mailing list
CIAC: DOE CIAC (Computer Incident Advisory Center) bulletins
CONFIRM: URL to location where vendor confirms that the problem exists
MLIST: generic reference form for miscellaneous mailing lists
RSI: Repent Security, Inc. security advisory
SF-INCIDENTS: posting to Security Focus Incidents mailing list
SNI: Secure Networks, Inc. security advisory
VULN-DEV: Posting to VULN-DEV mailing list

section.p: The above keywords are in full compliance with the CVE recommended keyword list found here.

section.name: procedure
section.title: Adding security related updates.
section.p: Security updates may only be applied once they have been verified by the original Author of the software which has been packaged for Fink and found to be vulnerable to a security issue. Before an update one or more of the following conditions have to be met:

ul.li: The author of the software has contacted the maintainer and/or the Fink Core Team. directly providing a patch or work around to a vulnerability.
One of the keyword donated sources has issued a security bulletin with updates sources for the software packaged for Fink in question.
A patch has been issued to one of the following keyword denoted sources: BUGTRAQ,FULLDISC,SF-INCIDENTS,VULN-DEV.
An official security bulletin has been issued and assigned CVE Candidate status, describing the vulnerability, supplying a work around, patch or link to updated sources.
Pre-notification has been sent to the maintainer and/or the Fink Core Team directly providing a patch or work around to a vulnerability asking to take action.

section.name: moving
section.title: Unstable to stable moves.
section.p: Security updates for a specific package will first be applied to the unstable tree. After a waiting period of no less than 12 hours the packages' info file will be moved into the stable tree as well. The retention period shall be used to carefully observe whether the updated package works and the security update does not introduce any new issues.
